-sY0HtYWy5lnm05tG8jdHQ.text: This is an upmarket Thai restaurant that is generally too expensive for what you get, but well worth a lunchtime visit using one of the 50%-off deals that are commonly available (e.g., try lastminute.com). The service and decor are very professional, it is popular as a business lunch place - not especially lively though. The room's very light and airy with windows all down one side. The food can be excellent - the chicken liver start was great.

Mk9VkHpFYbmWP-P9kF5iwQ.text: Worst meal ever. horrible seat, missing cutlery and dips. smelly and chewy prawns and way too expensive for the horrible food they serve. i sent an email complaining and all they've done was ask for our reservation details. doubtless to say, never going there again! save you money for a better thai restaurant.

KYhuKFb4mN30ZxuSc8exfg.text: Decent food, average service, overpriced cocktails, but good variety and a nice atmosphere. Beautiful location and quick turnaround so overall- an adequate night out.

DuH3kysjGhcStbk2ZWn2NQ.text: Fantastic upscale restaurant that I have been to several times since 2008. Like everyone else, I also tend to think that The Mango Tree is on the pricey side (maybe not even that surprising, given its rather exclusive location). My experiences there have been very good. To be fair, I used the omnipresent vouchers cutting my food bill by 50% - hence, I may be somewhat biased. Nonetheless, the service was very friendly (I was very impressed with the staff offering to put on my coat for me), courteous and (relatively) efficient. I have also been quite pleased with the food, particularly given how selective and, frankly, critical I tend to be at times. This is a truly lovely Thai restaurant - however, I deduct one star for its rather inflexible table turnover policy, which results in you not being able to stay beyond 1/1/2 or 2 hours. But yeah, other than that wonderful food in a commensurate atmosphere.

gCPmF19eU0lUfsnRyu9d3g.text: The food was good but the vegetarian menu was very limited and the service chaotic. The Blue Elephant in Fulham wins hands down.

mQBZDz6xC3uBqlSp26aL8Q.text: Smart place with nice food. A bit expensive but probably worth it for the quality. Only issue is that portions are not great so you have to order many dishes to get full and so the total cost is high.

JvQ0h_1rhR-uTg728P4TWQ.text: Lunch set was well prepared with reasonable price! Good to go with business associates and friends as well.

JF6gELxl5q8jQi7M3UY6EA.text: Excellent food with excellent atmosphere, but without the hole in your wallet. That is, if you go with one of the promotions available from various websites. Great place for a date or special occasions

uf287kPQK_50rh3nLBxm7w.text: Arriving here ridiculously early, as tends to happen when my mother is involved, we were asked to sit in the bar area whilst our table was prepared. The staff were very patient and nodded politely whenever Mum tried to hurry them up in her mad panic of thinking we would not make it to the Royal Albert Hall in time for the show. Having booked online, so as to receive half price food, we found that despite its location and swish appearance, the prices were really quite reasonable. Portions were decent sized to the point where it was impossible to finish our meal, but would probably seem less substantial if you were not eating quite so early. Go for this place if you are grabbing a quick meal between arriving at Victoria and going to a nearby theatre.

INm0dDmlm6LPk3rNXgfIbA.text: Went there with a toptable 50% off reservation. The food was possibly as good as Thai food can go and was quite delicious and quickly served. Their non-alcoholic cocktails were very expensive but tasty. On each table you would find some prawn crackers that I didn't like that much but I didn't like crackers that much in the first place.Highly recommended for the deep pocketed and for those who make the booking using toptable website.One word of caution though for those who do book through top table. the 50% offer is for many items in the menu but not all. All the good items marked as chef's special will have 25% discount instead.Prices for two courses of food without discount in around 25  30£

aCaVoUWHwQ-z9jzE8MbTLA.text: Not really sure what to make of Mango Tree. It is pretty spendy to say the least, and at close to £10 a cocktail don't plan on getting drunk over dinner unless you have much deeper pockets than me. Given the cost of these drinks you'd expect they would attempt to ram them down your throat, but actually the service is pretty inadequate and I had to ask to be served a couple of times. The food is a bit more reasonably priced, but not spectacular, and combined with a so so atmosphere I think there are much better options in London. However, depending on what kind of deal you can find on toptable, it might be worth checking out.

6q7PjdJy2AA0Ky7rfSwoJw.text: I want to like The Mango Tree - I really really do. After all, numerous people flock here, so THEY obviously like the food. But this must be my worst restaurant review thus far (and trust me, no matter how bad the food is, I usually try to give sympathy points). However, having given this restaurant 2 chances to convert my Nays to Ayes, I'm finally ready to throw in the towel. My latest visit (28/06/09) was a near disaster. We ordered 2 starters - Chicken Satay and Thai Fish Cakes. I KNOW my satays - having grown up a steady diet of these grilled kebabs. They almost always grace the table each time I visit a Singapore/Malaysian/Thai restaurant. When I took the first bite of satay from Mango Tree, my first thought was.. hmm, this tastes a bit 'off/odd' - something wasn't quite right. And my goodness, it arrived lukewarm, an almost unpardonable sin for this BBQ/Grilled meat item. But then I dismissed it as.. every restaurant does it differently, and besides.. my dinner companion and myself were famished. We tucked in with gusto annihilating 2 sticks of satay within minutes. We decided to split the 3rd stick - that was when I paid more attention to cutting up the meat. To my horror, I realised the meat was completely pink inside - totally RAW!! No wonder it 'tasted funny'!! Now, I like my Sashimi, but I don't rate chicken meat very high on the raw scale. I showed my discovery to a horrified waiter who promptly whisked the offending plate away. He promised to 'replace' it with another satay dish - this time, properly grilled. We didn't have to wait too long - the dish arrived within 10 minutes, this time piping hot, and properly cooked within. But the damage had been done - you cannot create a 1st impression a 2nd time. That said, I've actually had satay at Mango Tree the 1st time I was there. I don't quite recall the experience (forgettable), but it probably didn't taste too awful either. It was passable, but not great. The thai fish cakes, on the other hand, were rather tasty (and served hot!). Perhaps, it was a mite on the tough side (very chewy), but it was perfectly acceptable. For the main course, I had ordered the Green Curry Chicken Udon - which turned out surprisingly tasty. The curry is a little thicker than some Thai restaurants, thus creating a stew-like gravy backdrop for the udon noodles, but it worked well. My only complaint is that there were only 4 small bite-size chunks of chicken in the rather miserly bowl of udon noodles (very small portion). The grilled vegetables within tasted a little raw, but I'm trying to dismiss that as part of the 'unique cooking style' for this dish. I can't possibly be THAT unlucky 2 times in a row!! If you're planning to try the Green Curry Chicken Udon noodles, do make sure you order a starter, or maybe even another main course - you're likely to feel hungry still, if you think you can get away with just the main course. Big portions aren't Mango Tree's strongest points (apparently, grilled meats aren't, either). Having given such a harsh review so far, I am hoping to tone down and give a more positive note to the other main course, the Stir-Fry Chicken with Cashew Nuts. However, I'd be lying if I called that dish tasty - Thai restaurants pride themselves for strong and tasty flavours. This chicken stir-fry was so bland (too little gravy as well) that I had to spice things up a bit by adding the green curry gravy to it, so as to add a little 'flavour', something I loathe to do, since it would affect the actual taste of the food. But there was just no taste to the chicken with cashew nuts! Finally something I can recommend from this restaurant. The desserts - we ordered their homemade ice cream (3 different scoops), which turned out fairly original. I especially liked mixing the ice cream with a bit of the sticky rice at the bottom of the bowl (yummy). The pandan flavoured scoop was probably the nicest.. and I can't quite decide if I like the chocolate with lemongrass still, I suppose the pink scoop (I can only guess it might be raspberry)is the most conventional of all, but probably the most boring. I liked the other 2 flavours better, since they're more exciting. The lychee cheesecake was nice, but a little soggy. Having made cheesecakes myself, I'm a little taken aback by the sogginess of this particular cheesecake, but I suppose, if you've survived all the previous courses, a little soggy cheesecake wouldn't horrify you too much. It's amazing - I went to Mango Tree with NO EXPECTATIONS this time round, because I'd been let down on my last trip. And yet, it's completely miraculous how they've managed to lower the bar to a level where no other restaurant has gone. If I seem unreasonably harsh, that is because.. this is an establishment which has made a name for itself for serving 'good food'. People actually go there to eat (it was packed on a Sunday evening!) and they have regulars! The restaurant has a

YPDBo0VNLUywqAG3_tsYow.text: I have been to Mango Tree a few times already but this time was the last one-unfortunately! we booked the toptable offer (50% off) but were told that it excludes "chef special"-well, at least half of the dishes on the menu were chef special! food wasn't very tasty (meat stringy and with gristles-beef and chicken), service very rushed (we were told at the entrance to vacate the table latest two hours later-nice welcoming!), coke not chilled at all... sorry, never ever again, not even with 50% off

dK69nGZSiFC-3KP7sfwx-A.text: Wow, now that was good Thai Food! It had that taste that you always think you must find in asia, this hint of a dry green curry in the backyard of your tung - delicious! And a very stylish Restaurant! And the staff so attentive! And at the end we asked for Mango sticky rice for dessert - man, that was delicious as well. I can't say much about the prices, we had a business meal, but I must say everything at this place was very nice. Just the dining room itself was a bit too open for my taste, but that's just me..

AdSZtqrrwM7zJjFagsqJaA.text: Mango Tree is a high end restaurant offering a great variety of top quality Thai food. The place immediately strikes the visitor with its grand interior, with modern furnishing, high ceilings and large windows with views onto the Grosvernor Place outside. The layout of the dining area is open and spacious and while it's bustling with customers, the tables are places at a good distance from one another. Most dishes are prepared well, with a modern luxury take on traditional Thai food. I particularly enjoy the hot and sour soup, spicy chicken salad wrap and the green curry dishes. By what I can judge, grilled and stir fry dishes, of which there is a plentiful choice, are pretty good as well. The service is also brilliant, with many professional staff happy to assist any minute, which certainly enhances the dinning experience. But quality of course comes at a price and Mango Tree is quiet expensive. The bill adds to about £100 per person for the full dinner including drinks. Given the high class atmosphere and great quality food, I think it's well justified by London standards though.

Tz7BJrIhJm4yDBayQs82RQ.text: The very funky, the extremely busy and the popular Mango Tree fully deserves its reputation as a favourite of many diners. Even though we changed our booking time a number of times we were pleased that when we arrived at the restaurant, despite the obvious number of people sitting around waiting for tables, that we were immediately seated. It was very clear that the waiters were under a lot of pressure to clear the tables as quickly as possible if the fact we were asked about 3 times in the first 10 minutes whether we were ready to order was any indication. Finally those around us got the hint and left us alone until we signalled the waiter for attention. The menu at Mango Tree is extensive (both drinks and food) and, aside from the fact we were busy chatting and catching up, just working out way through the menu took us quite some time (food came very quickly once we did order though.) Mango Tree was a very pleasant experience. Service, apart from the sort of rushed start, was fantastic and friendly. Food was top notch and cocktails, including a nice array of non-alcoholic ones, were very tasty. The only drawback was the price -the £15.50 a curry without rice gives you an indication - quite highly-priced for Thai food. You can capitalise on deals though top table though which give you 50% which brings the price back to something a bit more value for money.

pmaqUIT-kcW5kiZdGr_t_Q.text: Had DH's birthday dinner here last here. pretty good. we were a pary of 8 so ofcourse they tagged on a gratuity. weird because some other places we went to refused a tip. I'd expect the addl charge in the US not in the UK.

couVp7G6fmM133yIy8xxvA.text: gorgeous restaurant, beautiful tasty food, good service, fun ambience.... 3 course meal with lots of wine is a little pricey which is the only negative point. definitely recommend! good pad thai!

qi4TJzNOIZBwIcnezMmIbA.text: To be honest, this is the best Thai restaurant experience i have ever had.  The food is great, atmosphere is nice, the staff very courteous and knowledgeable.  Drinks were fantastic, authentic and priced well, for London.  The food is exceptional and as good as it gets for Thai food.  We had a feast and I will certainly go back next time I'm in London.  Highly recommend!

biWiiY4MaWySO0l_zjjbOg.text: As far as Thai restaurant fine dining goes, the Mango Tree is about as good as it gets. I wouldn't quite consider us regulars but, if we have some spare cash and happen to be in London, then this is one of the places that we invariably end up at time and again. The dining room is clean and modern, seating comfortable and tables not packed too closely. The food itself offers some normal Thai food together with more elegant dishes. All of it, though, cooked to absolute perfection. The staff are all extremely friendly and attentive and will go to great lengths to ensure that every aspect of your night out is as perfect as the food you are eating. My only warning though, is that your local Thai restaurant will seem very second rate after you have eaten here.

3He2w3x_a5cKprsdxgfBdQ.text: Mango Tree is a large, Asian style restaurant near Victoria train station. It offers modern, fusion style food with lots of variety and choice. Wait staff are efficient, however you do sometimes get the feeling that the place is slightly chaotic beneath the polished veneer and nice decor. The main reason to come back is the food is reasonably good quality food and authentic, for a good price in central London. And, if you book by Toptable you can get discounts or points.

JVxsBX5fJkm2xrtvKLaiyw.text: Ooh The Mango Tree is a secret delight, this is as upmarket as it will get for Thai cuisine. It is very close to Victoria Station and corners the opposite end of Buckingham Palace! The Mango Tree is hidden on the edge of fancy office blocks, almost unnoticable unless you really know it's there. It is an exquisite dining location, very romantic and intimate with clean, modern and comfortable surroundings. The food we had was just great, It looked and tasted fantastic. However the prices were just a little on the higher end. I arranged for our Xmas Office party last year - we had an absolutely fantastic time, although it was a round table sit down, we were able to enjoy good quality food that everybody enjoyed. (Vegetarian colleagues) and then we were able to continue with drinks elsewhere. Use the Guardian Restaurant Reviews to book the meal and get 50% off..

GxgsqgAhYUy3m1nZB6peag.text: I had never really seen an upmarket Thai restaurant before I went to Mango Tree. I had always thought of little neighborhood Thai places with plastic tablecloths, sweaty cooks and fantastic cheap food. Mango Tree is different. It brings the romance of fine dining to the flavours of Thailand, right here in London. As soon as I walked in the door I could see that this was no neighborhood noodle place. The interior is immaculate, and the waiters numerous and impeccibly dressed. And the food. The food is incredible, the best curry I have eaten, and presented in a creative and colourful way. My only complaint? The prices. This place is not cheap, but here's the tip: Keep your eye out for special deals. Mango Tree seem to use special deals to keep the restaurant full, because without the common punters in there for a bargain slice of the high life, I think it would be pretty quiet mid week. Their website often advertises the deals on at the moment, and lastminute.com also has set meal deals most of the time. It's a winner, but only at the right price!

Y7vkzCZ2teHSpPYk8CzoRA.text: Mango Tree is a very elegant Thai restaurant set in Belgravia. It's decor is modern, sleek and refined. The food is excellent but pricey. The Thai Greencurry is one of the best I have ever had, whilst there is lots of option for non-meat eaters too. Whilst Mango Tree is expensive there are always special offers available for it. Plus tell them its your birthday and you get a free mini birthday cake :-) Highly recommended if you are looking to take someone who loves Thai out for a special treat.

4t_KtsWH52op_n0GS0RfSw.text: Thai is my favourite type of food and I'm almost always amazed by the flavours whether I'm in the local Thai place round the corner or somewhere more fancy like Patara. The Mango Tree definitely thinks its in the second category. This is clear from the attentiveness of the staff when you arrive and the way they smoothly usher you off into the bar for a cocktail while you wait to be seated. My first issue arose on the way to our table  the dining room is big and very well lit, with probably too many tables squeezed in. Most tables were taken so it was crowded, bright, and very noisy. As a result the ambiance didn't work for me. I ordered soft shell crab to start and a spicy stir fired prawn dish for main course. Both were fine but tasted like western versions of Thai dishes, lacking the real flavour kick I normally experience with Thai food. As a result this was probably my most disappointing experience ever in a Thai restaurant. The prices were pretty steep too. We had a 40% toptable discount, but sneakily this doesn't apply to Chef's choice dishes which it turned out included half the menu!

iSQL5omrPEHWEoVuVVy8iw.text: Both the food and service here was really really good! The venue itself was also very nice and the whole place seemed to run well. My only negitive is that it is fairly expensive. We booked on TopTable, so got a discount but it was still fairly pricy. Having said that, I think it was still worth it and would recommend it!

QorlyRGi7_kthHhFGX3D8A.text: A very busy place with good, but not exceptional, Thai food. The prices are fairly high - so it is good to check out special offers on toptable or tastelondon before going - as otherwise it can turn into a really expensive night!

cAnL9tz1TD-GKsYK_l_YFA.text: I did the naff American tourist thing and had Thai High Tea.  The food was expensive (30 quid for the lot), but fantastic, and the service was very attentive.  I can't wait to go there again next time I'm back in London.

E1uRfSsgsU8VsIKJCAZSww.text: Two visits in the last year. Very average food for the price, slow service and staff did not know anything about the menu! Eg asked to suggest something mild led to a steaming hot chilli dish coming out!There are much better restaurants in london.

s2kx1i83_QgCrpp5mJPHvQ.text: I do love me some Thai, so was quite excited to try out Mango Tree on Friday night. I was expecting good things after reading the reviews on Yelp, but sadly left disappointed. Two of us arrived at 7pm without a booking but got a table easily as long as we were out by 9pm- completely fine. The service was attentive and efficient, water re-filled prompty etc- no complaints there. The place looks great and has definite atmosphere. We had a Gin Fairy and Amaretto Sour from the huge cocktail list- they were fine but nothing special although the presentation was nice. But I found the food definitely lacking. Appetizers of vege spring rolls and spicy grilled aubergine salad were ok- the spring rolls were quite tasty but was disappointed in the salad- it was greasy, had almost no flavour and certainly no spice! For mains we had a vegetable red curry and stir-fried veges with cashew nuts. The flavours in the curry were quite nice- fragrant and delicate but the sauce was too creamy-heavy and there was no spicy kick at all in it. The stir-fry was...a stir fry. It was nicely cooked- not overdone, but there was a soy-sauce based sauce on it which was just bland. Perhaps Mango Tree caters for the carnivores better as reviewers with meat dishes seem to have fared better...Overall, at £68 for 2 meals and a cocktail each (we had no discount voucher etc) it was far too expensive for what we got- there is better Thai about for a much better price!

M87uS0pmJmGVbDx3E0jxTw.text: By far the best Thai food i have had  ever.Thai Mojitos to start then squid appetizer, Duck salad and Lamb lerb. It came with mushrooms and a really tangy sauce. Service was awesome and the entire experience was just top notch.A bit on the pricey side but I guess you pay for what you get. it was worth every pound. If i lived in London id have to dine here regularly :)

PamYnIvY7gIjGnJZxx8yrw.text: Pics@Chopstix2Steakniveschopstix2steaknives.blog… A group of us met up and walked in around lunch time and we found ourselves to be the only diners there. Now, Mango Tree is really huge with numerous tables and when you find yourselves to be the only table there in such a vast space, it does lend an uncomfortable silence of you-can-hear-a-pin-drop vibe to the place. In fact, we only saw one other occupied table throughout our meal there. After our lunch, all I can say is that the whole meal was quite forgettable and I wasn't blown away by any of the dishes.

K-Wcc907Vn2ww5JdJ5bqJA.text: I've been to the Mango Tree quite a few times. It's probably the best place to eat in Victoria (sort it out Victoria!). I'm a big fan of Thai food and I think their seasonal specials are what makes this a better than average Thai restaurant. The Thai green curry is good not amazing, similar to the Pad Thai. The starters are pretty average, but then Thai fish cakes and spring rolls are either good or not good in my book. They have some great cocktails and I think the waiting staff have always been fabulous. There's a nice bar on entry if you arrive early and they have some killer cocktails. Well worth a visit and pretty reasonably priced, it's just not mind blowing.

J3yL3BdV1jowlVo49WrfEg.text: I recently went here for a friend's birthday and was immediately impressed with the opulent interior. The orchids and dark wood combined with dim lighting provides a warm atmosphere.  However we were slightly disappointed that our table was not ready even though my friend had reserved a table a week before!We waited in the bar and enjoyed some red wine and were eventually seated at our large circular table along the back wall. We waited a while which was disappointing considering we had had to wait for our table. My yellow curry monk fish was very tasty with lots of flavour and I could not fault the food. However one of my friends was given the wrong order and was made to feel difficult when she asked for her dish.Mango Tree is definately one of the finest looking restaurant in London and I think the price reflects its location and interior. I have tasted better Thai food in smaller less luxorious restaurants but I would still return to Mango Tree for a special occassion. Hopefully someone else will be paying!

photos.caption: Photo of The Mango Tree - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Mango Tree - London, United Kingdom

eZfjAAxGZSOss8AKyqKYbg.text: Wow, colour me impressed. And full. And broke. And ready to do it again tomorrow. The Mango Tree wasn't cheap, so let's get that out of the way early. You'll pay for deliciousness, but it's actually quite a fair deliciousness-to-cost ratio, so you won't leave grumpy. As Matt pointed out, the address is Grosvenor Place, Belgravia... so welcome to my world - where it literally costs me £10 to sneeze. (Maybe I should look up the definition of 'literally'... but I'll save that for another time.)With that out of the way, I may now begin to review-drool all over the place with how amazing each dish was. Portions were healthy, flavours were fantastic and completely different dish by dish, spice was spot on, and menu creativity was high. (Red duck curry in a carved out pineapple? Yes please!) We had beef. We had chicken. We had swordfish, and prawns, and scallops, and duck, and tuna, and squid, and they were all complimented by the freshest of veggies and perfectly cooked egg fried rice and glass noodles. The multiple sauces were also divine with some of the tastiest peanut sauce I've had to date. Last but not least, the dessert was unspeakably good - homemade chocolate and lemongrass ice cream with two heaping brownies drizzled in warm chocolate sauce. Seriously, I can't even talk about it. It was perfection.The venue layout is quite grand and stylish, although I'm not sure how I felt about eating shot-gun style where I was closer to my neighbours than my dining partner. There were some fantastic round group tables which I definitely would prefer in the future.Overall, if you're looking for a place to eat some amazing food (and are willing to drop a bit of cash,) this should definitely be your go-to spot. Hell, just go for dessert and cocktails! It was truly a fabulous evening. Highly highly recommended.

nQ2B3I-4kU4KfvdKI07MLA.text: Whenever someone says, 'let's get Thai', I groan inside. Call me an obstinate twat, but I am the only person I know who does not really like it. Which is weird because they add peanuts to everything... what's not to love?!!Dear Mango Tree, you saucy minx, you seduced me over to the Thai darkside.  A menu full of my favourite things from seafood to dishes served in a carved out pineapple. (I think you are all familiar with my love of the ridiculous, novelty food being number one!) By our powers of ordering combined, we devoured scallops, shrimp, swordfish,  steak salad, duck and satay sauce, that was like heaven itself. Eamon B introduced me to cha-yen, Thai tea, which is creamy, fruity and sweet. Loved it. Leave room for dessert, specifically the best, sophisticated brownie and chocolate ice-cream, you will ever eat.

tPtyGbxhoLgxg7JEONkFAQ.text: Nice food but the restaurant its far too big... when its busy, the place gets so crowded and noisy that you can hardly have a conversation!Food is alright, and cocktails quiet overpriced. Dont go if you are looking for a romantic/quiet place for dinner, chat and relax.Worth it if you are a Tastelondon card member (50%off food bill up to 8 people) and if you dont mind loud places, you just going for a nice thai dish.

2h04jmyzNlLCGFQmqgF4og.text: A friend of mine made a reservation here on Toptable and we were going with her parents so price wasn't really an issue on the night, however, if we were not there with a 50% discount and being bankrolled by parental units then I don't think I would ever have crossed its threshold.I did enter the ginormous space and even though they knew we had booked on Toptable, they still treated us like VIPs. We went for wine at the bar first, although after sneaking peeks at everyone around us and their cool looking cocktails, I wish i had tried one.The menu was enormous, and it had a great vegetarian and vegan section but it took as long to pick out what we wanted to eat as it did for us to eat it. That being said, what we finally decided on was delicious, especially the Gae Yang (lamb in the grill section of the menu). Although it was a bit too pricey for my budget, I will definitely go back when my parents are in town.

ejC52twD_ca4eVMSGNrmtA.text: Very good service overall, had the Tom Yum soup with Prawn, but I honestly can't believe that I just paid £7 for this little bowl of soup though... normally most place, you can get a pot for that price. The panang curry was a OK, not bad but not outstanding either. The stir fried basil dish was pretty good, but again, not really worth the price. And I was really surprised that they actually charge you for rice per bowl... £3 per serving ?!?!? seriously ?!  I never came across a Thai restaurant in US or in Asia that charge for the rice. Is this a UK thing or is this just the restaurant? The service was ok, our waitress was kinda robotic ... didn't show any interest of serving the customer... but again, it seems that is the case in UK in general. Overall good ambient but again overpriced ... averaging £35 per head for a soup and an entree .... not really worth it.

mcHpD7IEkxoq8I6Wp1W1BQ.text: OK to good food + variable service + moderate proportions + high prices + nice ambiance = Mango Tree. Mango Tree just barely escapes with three stars but it is really a 2.7. For value shoppers out there, this is not the place to go. I have eaten similar quality Thai food at dozens of establishments in the western world for roughly 1/4th the price. After three visits I can say the currys are quite good (though small), and the noodle or stir fry dishes are nothing special. No matter what I order though I will always think the same thought, "did I really just pay 20 pounds for that". 3/4ths of the price goes to the ambiance, and 1/4th the food.

vbPvnq2mGcR9eT8d6Qwj6A.text: Why is it that every popular Asian/Asian Fusion restaurant in London has the worst acoustics???  You may as well be in a club!  I had high hopes that the posh-looking Mango Tree would be an exception, but alas, no.  Overpowering white noise snuffs out any attempt at decent conversation at this place.  Clattering flatware and the muffled rumblings of other diners forces you to shout: "WHAT???? AGAIN PLEASE!!!!" to your neighbour.  And believe me, if you're in a group, you're neighbour is the ONLY one you have a hope of conversing with.  Ugh.  No wonder conversation is a dying art... there's nowhere to practice it.On the upside, I was the glad the acoustics were bad as I'd always regretted the fact that my ex-bf and I had chosen the equally noisy E&O over Mango Tree for a romantic Thai birthday dinner.  Regret begone!I didn't dislike the food at Mango Tree - I didn't love it - but it was fine.  A touch pricey, perhaps - but if you book online and get the 50% off coupon, it could almost be considered cheap.  I had the vegetarian Pad-Thai, which was a little weird because there were no noodles and no peanuts - just strips of tofu and a few veggies (i know, i know, did they bring me the right dish?) - for you Americans out there, the taste was actually reminiscent of the veggie lettuce wraps at P.F. Chang's.  So.. not terrible, just not at all what I expected.Sadly, the terrible acoustics and the 'eh' food is really just too bad since if there's one thing Mango Tree did have, it would be the most attentive, politest, how-in-the-world-can-we-possibly-please-you service I think I've ever had in London.  We had several servers tending to us and they were all incredibly courteous... verging on endearing.  I may go back simply to feel like a princess again.

d22UFZkEdR0BFWHzHMBbPQ.text: WOW !!! I am not sure how to do my review after reading through the lovely reviews on this resturant done by others.To delicately put it, the best part of this resturant was their customer service and their ambience. I would not recommend this place for Thai.

kXYFGC7Q3SdYAR43sjrtMA.text: Went here on a Toptable booking, which gave a discount or a set menu option. However after looking at the regular menu the prices are quite reasonable anyway.The Mango Tree is a very busy restaurant so can be rather noisy especially if there's just 2 of you, however I would definitely come back with a group of friends as the atmosphere is lively, the food is yum and the service is excellent. There is also a good list of cocktails.All in all a good evening out.

mkC3bDroqhsaiJj4qFzUKQ.text: Yummy food, attentive staff!  Spicy but not too spicy!  Fantastic dinner on our first night in London!  Look forward to see what's next.

8T2xgJLqmo_BSJUxRueNIw.text: This is literally my favorite Thai restaurant in the world (and I've even been to a few very good ones in Thailand), it is actually the sister restaurant of the Mango Tree restaurant in Bangkok so everything is very authentic.  The decor is sleek and modern.  The place gets very crowded yet it still maintains a warm atmosphere and it does not get too loud making it very appropriate for business dinners.  Service is friendly and very attentive, the wait staff is very knowledgeable on the food and wine list and very good at making recommendations based on your preferences.  The Som Tum salad (papaya salad) is a very traditional Thai dish and always perfectly prepared. Everything is served family style so you can try a variety of dishes.  Excellent wine list.  It is quite popular so be sure to book reservations.

3Pbtkttiv8Tk0zB7X_hapA.text: The food was totally lame, lacking taste or freshness I would expect at the price level.  The stir fry was lacking - some spice and soy sauce was what the sauce seemed to be, the spring rolls were dry and tasteless, and the chicken and lamb (so dry, you're gnawing on it continuously to eat it) satay was dry and over cooked.  The staff was pleasant, but the ambiance is upscale snootiness without the food to back it up.  the dessert was good - Honey Mango and Sticky Rice.  They also required us to buy 3 appetizers or dessert since we made a booking online?!?  Total crap, Don't go there.

lh9_DWY2JAzdiepQ7dLt6A.text: Elegant, great food, great staff and calm. Love it for nice dinners for work of friends.

JPuhxjhGTPpsEnvXHuk2gQ.text: Great food. Not the best thai in London, but very, very good.Good cocktails. Nice bar area to wait in if you get there early. Not a destination bar.Large open room which means a very loud restaurant. Better for groups than a couple as the portions are large and with Thai food it is always nice to have a variety.

Ae_6jDqFxt4U1r8aMAODsw.text: Mango Tree is firmly just okay. Their service is a little slow and their thai food is on the mediocre side while being very overpriced. I've tried the Gai Yang (chicken marinated in coconut milk along with other stuff), Pad Thai, and the BBQ pork starter. All were decent, but definitely not worth the price. The restaurant itself is pretty large and I guess they hold different events there on occasion? On my way out I saw a sign for a Ladyboy Competition, coming up soon!

wNuDonP5iQ4qL-lAcxI0RA.text: While shopping at Harrods, boyfriend and I stopped at Mango Tree for a quick lunch break.  Mango Tree is asian fusion with an emphasis on dim sum that they say is made fresh daily by a Hong Kong dim sum master.  I really liked the feeling of sitting at the "bar" of an open kitchen where we could watch the chef at work and our servers within arm's reach.  While waiting for two seats to open up, the hostess took our order so that once we were sat, our food was ready and ready it was.  Our servers were courteous and efficientWe ordered the blooming jasmine flower tea served in a clear glass tea kettle for two.  I found the tea quite tasty and LOVED the tea set and watching the flower bloom, so pretty.  I asked if the tea set was available for purchase at Harrods and while the servicegirl admitted it was, she recommeded I check out an asian tea shop in chinatown as it would be much cheaper.  Loved her for that! I started with the Prawn and Pork Wonton soup (8.50) which arrived three small dumplings in a small bowl in a clear broth.  Although small, the soup was tasty nonetheless. We also ordered a few dim sum dishes since the dumplings were mostly served in threes.  We ordered the prawn dim sum (7.95), Inside soup dumpling dim sum (19.50), and spare rib dumpling (7.50).  Dumplings were yummy but with the pound kicking the dollars butt, our check total without tip amounted to 60something pounds or roughly $100something USD and I don't know about you but I can get a shitload of dim sum for the kind of money here in the states (holla Chinatown NYC or Arlington VA) and it probably tastes just as or even more delicious and authentic.  But at least we can say we ate lunch at Harrods!  Their food court and options sure beats any food court here in the states.

gyUuyhd1HWzGuJSEF8Fedw.text: Surprisingly busy around nine-thirty on a Sunday, however the staff tried their hardest to run a tight shift, some waiting but we were eventually seated and the service was great. Being a student initially I thought it was quite expensive, however once we'd all ordered the portions and pricing were reasonable, the food was lovely. Although one of my friends did get food poisoning and I'm not quite sure of what they ordered sorry. My experience here was decent, but I'm not asking to go back.

photos.caption: Photo of The Mango Tree - London, United Kingdom. Mango Tree

Bs8f1YXb6hjCdr88IDqIRQ.text: one of the better places to eat around the area. service was very precise and professional. I have noticed friendliness and good service is  not the same as it is back in Los Angeles so this was a good change. the Thai iced tea was delicious. just be sure to ask for no ice as they fill up the entire cup with ice and the tea lasted three sips :(the panang curry was very tasty, good spice to it. the sirloin steak fry was good too but overall for $100 dollars (about 60 pound or so) for our meal I would have expected either more food or a free refill of tea without all I've :)this place does have many options to choose from but the overall value is not there. if you want food food and don't mind the pricing, this is the place for you.

jVxJlma8tW_DVjifEI5YRg.text: The bar and ambience of the restaurant was nice and of the standard that you would expect of a central London restaurant. The service was attentive. Despite having a separate vegetarian menu, I would argue that the selection was still fairly limited and the food distinctly average. This combined with a rather hefty bill will probably rule out any hasty return.

Q2S5fuFlUcElbshXRxgqFA.text: We tried their 3-course set menu the other day.  Fish Cakes were very thin and lacked flavour and the Papaya Salad just tasted vinegar - where're the dried shrimps?  Main course of Chicken with Cashew Nuts was bland and very mediocre.  Only the desserts - ice cream with sticky rice, and cheesecake - were just passbale but nothing to write home about.A couple at the next table returned their cocktail because something fishy was floating.  We also saw some half-eaten plates returned to the kitchen.  The prices are high and their cooking standard doesn't match it:  very bad value for money.  If you would like to have very authentic Thai in an elegant setting, try Thai Thai near Old Street Tube.  They offer much better value and their cooking is wonderful.

sLiNS4KENzYNFvmFE1OW1A.text: This place has so much potential - you can see that by the layout of the restaurant, the friendly staff, etc but the food falls flat - extremely disappointing. The 2 main courses we tried (chicken with cashews and beef with oyster sauce) were very bland and tasteless. To be honest I could have cooked this meal much better myself, which is a real shame and NOT the point of going out for dinner.

-sfIlcJCdsHTMLIf98KZwA.text: The food was great but the service was horrendous!

q8ASJCJMT5YhHQIj-YIYgw.text: Good food, great service but pretty expensive. That type of restaurant and level of service would have been less expensive in the U.S. London overall has pricey restaurants and you seem to have to pay a lot to get a decent meal. If you've got the money and want to enjoy a good meal, then go to The Mango Tree.

2DfNnJ-fXcI5v1wrMWz-nw.text: Really enjoyed my dining experience here. Amazing customer service and love that the staff know the menu inside out! Really enjoyed their cocktails and my food was cooked to perfection!

QM0KKqe6sMG65sdesR8O-g.text: DinnerThe jasmine tea didn't have an aroma.Pad Thai was horrible. I prefer them adding lots of coconuts, peanuts with thinner noodle. How possibly could go wrong? In this case I should have ordered deli who is cheaper but can cook much better manner.Tom yum needs more lime juice?

photos.caption: Photo of The Mango Tree - London, United Kingdom. Pad Thai.
Photo of The Mango Tree - London, United Kingdom. Tom yum

omblRluwDwpZXVOybtonDg.text: I have no need to eat again this week as I'm still stuffed from last night. The Mango Tree is everything you would expect from a restaurant in Grosenvor Place, Belgravia and I probably wouldn't eat here again unless there is a special offer. Even with 50% off this bill was still more than £20 each between four of us.The food was excellent, I have no complaints about my beef sirloin salad and the main course of chicken fillet with peppers. A glance away from my plate showed a table full of happy diners too. The dessert was divided by 4 and there was still plenty to go around especially as I felt like Mr Creosote from Monty Python's The Meaning of Life (the wafer thin after diner mint is still in my wallet).The restaurant is on the large side as opposed to intimate  with the toilets a bit of a trek down the stairs but it was packed at 9:15 on a Sunday night so they must be doing something right.

VQybUb7miTTV1d5DOL3fWw.text: I ate here during my few day stay in the UK , actual date was 7/17/12.The place was nice, busy crowded, seemed like a ton of dates happening at once..Chose to eat here as it was right behind Buckingham Palace. Food was average, service, ehh, could have been better (perhaps if the staff moved a little!). Drinks was great. People obviously go for ambiance..

HwaJQ3wAEV3SWQP2oID7XQ.text: The Mango Tree is the only place I ever go for Thai. Everything, from the food to the decor, is simply gorgeous. In the evening it has a perfect atmosphere; dimly lit, confident yet inviting, with a hint of the exotic. I usually go with a group of friends and we always sit at one of the circular tables along the back wall where you can get a great view of the grand interior not to mention the food gliding past you on the arms of the well polished waiters as you chat. Our waiter once even told me the whole room has been feng-shui designed to ensure a perfect dining experience. The photo really doesn't do it justice as the chocolate coloured wood contrasting with bright orange orchids in itself looks good enough to eat.Having a great experience here is effortless, for a start, the food is delicious. There's a fabulous cocktail menu that we usually begin with, skipping the first course. For the main I usually go for Gaeng Garee Pla, a yellow monkfish and butterfish curry, or the Moo Nam Pueng, slow roasted pork belly with red cabbage and an orange chilli sauce. Although often we order a few dishes between us and try them all (trust me, when you see the food you will want a taste of everything on the entire menu). The desserts are divine too, my favourite being the Lavender Rose and Kalamansi sorbets, both delicate flavours to finish with. Whilst the staff are always happy to advise on the extensive wine list. I suggest you try the 1999 Barolo, a seriously good all rounder. The service is impeccable, although I do find the girl in the bathroom who's waiting subserviently, with eyes lowered, to dry your hands a bit OTT. Channel polish or not, I think everyone can just about manage to do that part themselves. I could go on forever complimenting The Mango Tree, it's just one of those places where such great food and attention to detail can't fail to provide you with the ingredients for a wonderful night. It's remained a firm favourite of mine over the years.Booking is essential.

HjE-0XRN1xmcOaYKjZMl7Q.text: I have been to Mango Tree for a corporate event, so the entire venue was booked and the menu was pre set.The food is okay, not the best thai in town but not bad at all, wine was good and the service was prompt and polite.However, it didn't impress me and I had the impression that it is an expensive place.

RuEAvNJcX_b2dVEHsa7f2A.text: nice Thai food and very friendly Thai waitress~ very recommend the Thai tea and the Thai cocktail!

photos.caption: Photo of The Mango Tree - London, United Kingdom. curry duck
Photo of The Mango Tree - London, United Kingdom. lobster

DkYohm2h_cNQG5X4jjHzVQ.text: average vegetarian to be honest.the green curry is a tad bland and i would say that i prefer spicier food but who goes to a thai restuarant to eat bland food? everyone seemed to be eating from the set men/opentable offer but its ok value for a meal in victoria

0NdagHW-zTd6itlFFmzMjQ.text: A group of us met up and walked in around lunch time and we found ourselves to be the only diners there. Now, Mango Tree is really huge with numerous tables and when you find yourselves to be the only table there in such a vast space, it does lend an uncomfortable silence of you-can-hear-a-pin-drop vibe to the place. In fact, we only saw one other occupied table throughout our meal there.After our lunch, all I can say is that the whole meal was quite forgettable and I wasn't blown away by any of the dishes.

JRwgR5JA8_k2gx7R16nTHQ.text: One of few decent, reasonably affordable options in Victoria. That being said, a two course business lunch with soft drinks and water only still came in at £40 a head. It's a relatively soulless barn of a space under a large hotel / office building, light and bright enough on the sunniest day of the year but little ambience delivered by the large plate glass windows staring out on the traffic choked Grosvenor Place. The decor feels a little scuffed and tired round the edges these days, and the confusing, tatty menu piles three special menus on top of the banqueting options on top of the a la carte. The £17 set lunch needs to be asked for separately however.I went for two from their seasonal Street Food Festival menu, unsure of what this was linked to but the options looked interesting enough. Kai Nok-krata Tord or Quail egg Wanton was a bit of a one trick pony. Pleasant enough, though a little cloying after a while, the portion containing six of the little orbs, hard boiled and fried in wanton skin, my anaemic chilli sauce had me eying a neighbours satay avariciously. The satay and associated chicken skewers were pronounced quite as good as anything my colleague had eaten recently in Thailand.My main was more interesting, deep-fried sea bass with a mango salad. The former came a touch over-fried for my taste, the accompanying chewy mouthfeel tasty for sure, but killed the sea bass a little. The green mango salad worked alongside, a cooling mix of crunchy matchsticks contrasting with the heat of the fish. Elsewhere they didn't seem to compromise on flavour for pedestrian local taste buds either. Other dishes receiving plaudits round the table included a robust Massaman Lamb Shank curry, thick, creamy and almost aggressively spiced with the soft lamb falling off the bone.Wines are fairly punchy in their ambition. I'm not sure I'd waste a premier Bordeaux on such spicy fare but if you would, then they're all here and priced as you'd expect. There's plenty around the £18 - £30 mark too though the professional workers (or those with bosses) weren't able to imbibe.Overall, it's difficult to fault the food that we had, though I might chose differently next time. Big portions of fresh and authentic, well spiced Thai banqueting specialities. But you'll pay handsomely for the privilege and if not stuck in Victoria with no escape I wouldn't necessarily travel for it. The ambience, decor and tightly packed tables rule out romantic rendezvous too. If you're craving expensive Thai in Victoria, Michelin starred Nahm on West Halkin Street is also worth a thought.

Bg0Oq29do94SwlKOyi6MOw.text: Great food and service. Really appreciated the waiter taking the time to point out the gluten free items to me. I recommend the mixed satay appetizer. Ambiance was open and sophisticated. The center tables were a bit close to each other.

qPi7GQG9aQWZYC0P6hNrNA.text: Thai to Try in LondonOn the recommendation of our hotel staff, we decided to give the Mango Tree a try.At home, we are in a Thai restaurant desert. We are always eager to try Thai restaurants when we are away from home. Mango Tree is a winner. Our dishes were served hot and full of that distinctive Thai flavor. Our dishes of Rack of Lamb and the Wok Seafood Assortment were excellent.The restaurant was very busy on a weeknight,but, this place is managed well with plenty of staff on the floor to keep things moving.Our dinners here were very good and we were very glad to have followed the advise of the hotel staff which worked out very well for us.

Fj8o6HM82LhrwLET8EsNdw.text: Spent £80 here on myself and ordered a variety of items: Tom yum soup (5/5), sea bass (3/5), soft shell crab "salad" (3/5), mango tree drink (4/5), bread pudding (2/5) and jasmine tea (2/5). Best dish: By far the most flavorful was the Tom yum. It had mushrooms and shrimp in a thick coconut broth. It's spicy so be warned. Worst dish: Sea bass was over cooked and over priced at £20. Doesn't come with rice and all you get is about a palm sized portion. I've had better quality sea bass for less. The lemon grass which is steamed with the fish didn't give off any flavors or fragrance.

tNiuECJpWnel6nPpUtXawQ.text: The service is very good, the setting is refined and the atmosphere relaxed but the food itself was mostly ordinary. Food is served with attention to presentation with the tofu starter, Pandan-leaf-wrapped chicken and egg mesh on top of the Pad Thai being visual highlights. The roast duck is very much a Cantonese dish and the seafood noodles are basically seafood ho fun. There is nothing wrong with the content of the dishes and they are of decent size but at the same time there was nothing extraordinary about them. My friends and I did not try any curry so cannot comment on that. Overall the price of the food seems a little extravagant for what is the type of food that you could essentially find at a typical restaurant in Chinatown. This seems more of a venue to impress a date with or to have a celebration with with one of their fancy-clad cocktails.

photos.caption: Photo of The Mango Tree - London, United Kingdom. Roast duck
Photo of The Mango Tree - London, United Kingdom. Seafood noodles
Photo of The Mango Tree - London, United Kingdom. Pad thai

gkU5aDNvr7gJtXYhijph2Q.text: I went for a friends birthday and it was really posh like, really nice for couples and small groups, for 11 of us the food and drinks came up to £572 in total, the food was really good no body complained and I enjoyed it, the food is spicy  (especially if you see it with the chillies)

photos.caption: Photo of The Mango Tree - London, United Kingdom

kRRYchlILkDP-BsRqLhyYg.text: My husband and I had dinner here tonight on recommendation by the concierge at our hotel. Food was average. Nothing to write home about. Service was poor. We asked for a refill on our prawn chips and they didn't bring it until we were finished with our meal. It was also a slow night for them so no excuse as to why it took them so long to deliver our appetizers, and finally our main entrees. However...they were quick to ask us if we wanted more bottled water. Unfortunately I'm not a big fan of having to pay nearly $5 (around $6 us) for a bottle of water that only filled two half glasses. We ordered the sampler appetizer plate for two, a prawn papaya salad, a single order of prawn Tom yum soup, a seafood stir fry, and a chicken pad Thai...bill came out to $94 (us $118). They tried to include a service charge of 12.5% on top of that cost too and there was only two of us, and our sleeping baby in her stroller. RIDICULOUS!! All I can say is that I've had better takeout Thai food from a random hole in the wall (I'm from Los Angeles where great Thai food is in abundance). If you are going to service charge two people, then I suggest you offer better service....or at the very least offer better portions for the prices you charge. Not worth the price...and not worth the time. I wish I actually had the chance to review the yelp ratings before we went to this place.

photos.caption: Photo of The Mango Tree - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Mango Tree - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Mango Tree - London, United Kingdom

LlGlMusUdlt4y5EXQXv8ZA.text: Food was good, but slow service.  They wouldn't let us get a drink from the bar until we were seated, but the main entrance comes into the bar??  Weird?  .food was good though

1tvK7jO3Wo92WoUktFpqBA.text: This was the second time I've been to Mango Tree and it was good in comparison to the first time! The food was great and the service was excellent. The only drawback was that it was for a family birthday and we did feel a bit rushed however that's probably to be expected as it was a Friday night. In terms of food, I definitely recommend the duck and the lamb massaman curry!!

photos.caption: Photo of The Mango Tree - London, United Kingdom. A sample of starters from their tasting menu.

VG66n9c58dNVVXjXohzkkw.text: Nice restaurant with good food (with lots of interesting dishes on the menu, as well as the classics) and service but ultimately it's very expensive for what it is. I would say if you want reliable Thai food and don't care about the price, this is good, but otherwise there just have to be other options that are better value. I enjoyed the sharp and spicy flavour tom yum soup but found my salad less interesting.

lz5-1Uc8L6TIuatIox6PFg.text: Pretty space but not special - satay served over a lighted candle. I think restaurants should offer filtered water at no charge. Not the case here. We declined half price offer and instead ordered a series of small plates. For some reason, that seemed to impact service despite ordering round of alcohol.

qCTWYafJ3hZye8DKxS-aug.text: The two most recent reviews really do not do The Mango Tree justice, I think they're a bit too harsh. Our experience was a a solid 3.5, though alas I have to round down in this case. They provide 'good' Thai food, with an above average experience from the staff, though not quite enough to tip the scales. Pad Thai was on the spot and a solid performer. The Sea Bass was quite good actually, with fresh mango /  chilis etc. in a lovely sauce. The Larb Gai was a bit heavy tasting for Thai food, though not unpleasant. For a nice finish to the meal we had a selection of their sorbet, with the highlight being the Lemograss version. Very good.

DTbkKMUrVcZn0HEHkZQfIA.text: We enjoyed a delicious birthday meal with excellent starters and main dishes. The food was fruitful, full of spices, and beautifully prepared. The aesthetics of the restaurant created a mystic yet intimate environment which paralleled our meals extremely well. Pop, our server, provided renowned service and catered to our every need alongside special meal requests. He and his team were extremely polite and professional with every move. We highly recommend this restaurant to anyone in the area and it is worthy of even a greater rating.

photos.caption: Photo of The Mango Tree - London, United Kingdom

rsfg4uvHH4JstyOXLPWa_w.text: I have visited 'The Mango Tree' on two occasions. My first experience was better than my second. Based on the second, I wouldn't go again.Food: The food is in general good. I think though it all depends on what you get. The first time I went we ordered loads of starters and I they were good. The second time I went for main dishes too. The chicken for one was didn't taste great and I ended up eating just the vgetables.Service: The service was quite good the first time I went (late dinner). The second time (early dinner/ late lunch), there were a lot of trainees. We had a menu in for quite some time and kept on trying to get our waiters attention for 15 mins. I felt like were were forgotten!Price: This place is pricey. The portions are small. This isn't a place where you get value for money. If you go for an early lunch, then there is a 'discounted' menu which makes it more worth it. Ambience: The staff in general is helpful and polite. The decor is okay but nothing to write home about.

3UknIOsgZQL2_29Ti5cUhA.text: Whenever in London, The Mango Tree is my go to spot for excellent Thai cuisine.  I love the food, the atmosphere is amazing, and they drinks are excellent. The curry entrees are all amazing and they offer very diverse and delicious options for starters.  The wine selection is extensive which is always a good sign as they take pride in their customers dinning experience.  When dinning at The Mango Tree it feels as if you are are sitting in an up scale restaurant and you're treated as such too. It's a large room which can accommodate a good amount of people but call ahead anyway because it fills quickly.  On most nights they close at 11PM which has saved me a couple time while entertaining colleagues after late night meetings.  If you like Thai and Stir Fry, The Mango Tree is a must try.

X7RvW2-IpZtP22nGBUFgiA.text: It's quite good quality Thai food here. Ordered the Pad Thai and it was substantially better than takeaway but at the level of Busaba and Thai Square. Opentable currently has a 50% off deal as well when you order a main and starter which makes this place pretty sweet at the moment. The Kor Moo Yang was surprisingly good as well as the Tom Ka Goong.

hvIkWnPkIWS-rOfEtLWuDg.text: This place is fantastic.  There is always a buzz here and service is second to none.  In fact I can't remember the last time I got such fantastic service.  The staff are knowledgeable, respectful and you will find your glass (either water or wine) is never empty.  They seem to pre-empt your every desire!The food is pretty amazing too.  There is a really good selection and for the me the beef dishes in particular were outstanding and the tempura soft shell crab (starter) was the dish of the day.Yelp I wish you would let me put in half stars on my reviews as the Mango Tree definitely deserves another half star.  My only crib is that it is  little pricey and the green papaya salad was not quite as delicious as some others I've had, although still very nice!  For that I have deducted a star (or half a star if you like). If you like Thai food you will not be disappointed and if in the area I heartily recommend giving this place a go.

rTe_9_MltG3FLXlWFS878Q.text: My small office came here for a Christmas party dinner. The food was good, but nothing super special, especially considering the price. They also were pretty sneaky about getting money out of us, knowing that it was on a company card and several of us were increasingly smashed as the night went on. First, the waitress asked everyone what their first course would be, instead of whether we'd even like a first course. Sneaky. We ordered one bottle of wine, but then they just kept bringing out more and refilling our glasses without asking with new bottles. I had to keep turning them away because I didn't want to drink very much. The bill turned out to be much larger than what we'd actually asked for.It seems like they make a lot of their money from the drinks here, as they have a bar too, and the wine I had was good. They don't put as much effort into their food as one might expect with this price range. Maybe this is a smart business practice, but it doesn't leave me with a very good feeling. Plus their service was often slow, and they seemed especially reluctant to refill our water glasses, which is a huge irritant to me especially when people are drinking alcohol.The ambiance is lovely - I especially enjoyed the Christmas trees, lights, and Christmas music - but I probably won't be coming back, with all the other choices of restaurants I have in London.

photos.caption: Photo of The Mango Tree - London, United Kingdom. Mango Tree dining room at Christmastime

WLXgGNlL5wFrB4uDKxLvKw.text: Went here to eat on a trip to London. We were touring the city and we had seen this place on a Gordon Ramsey show, we noticed this place was close to where we were going to be so we decided to give it a try. We came in for lunch and they had just opened. They brought us complimentary prawn skins but we are vegetarians so we couldn't eat those.  Our meal was very mediocre at best. We thought it would have been so much better and would have had a few better options for us but we were wrong. The place was nearly empty and they sat two loud and annoying business men directly next to us as if there were no other seats. The staff was helpful and pretty friendly. But this place has so much potential and we expected so much better but we were disappointed.

UaVYm26TxGMTELoBKu4znQ.text: Woman at restaurant called me a shit - all because I said they charged my card 2 x's. She td my 9 year old all Americans are shits and they should all die as she spit the words In her face. She is exactly why people are afraid to travel. My 9 year old want to leave London as soon as possible.

kNf2e334nIKeTB19p6qqyw.text: I'm very judgemental most Thai food outside of Thailand. I will nearly always find some fault in authenticity (as much as I hate that word because wow snobbery), but I also understand restaurants need to work within the confines of both what's available and what's expected, and I think The Mango Tree does this.The vegetarian menu is completely vegan, which is a nice contrast to most Thai restaurants where fish and oyster sauces are considered fair game in the veggie department. My meal included the som tam, a favourite when I am in Thailand. The salty/sour/sweet balance was perfect, but it lacked chili and yard long bean chunks and could have done with something funky to replace the lack of fish sauce (although the dish wasn't completely devoid of that flavour profile).For my main I enjoyed the choo chee aubergine, which was rich and gorgeous as a choo chee sauce should be.Despite sounding negative about the place, I would quite happily return. It's rare to find Thai food that's remotely like what you'd get in Thailand (news flash: green curry does not exist on every Thai menu), but The Mango Tree will please the wider population, with a few dishes for devoted Thai food fans, and it's really nice to see a mainstream restaurant promoting a vegan friendly selection of dishes.P.S. the cheap house white is not worth it. Spend a couple quid extra to drink not that.

aNHXRZv5lmxS5OtaKdUFVA.text: I had seen this restaurant on Gordon Ramsay's Best Restaurant, and had walked past it a few times in my lunch break, and have been dying to eat here since then. So when i was in charge of organising a celebratory work dinner, i knew this was my chance to feast!!The reservation process was quite easy, and the staff were super friendly and helpful. Upon entering the restaurant, we were greeted by smiley faces, who were very welcoming. After putting our coats in the cloak room, we were shown to our table. Majority of our group were having the set menu, however a few of us had allergies and needed to order from the al a carte menu. The wait staff were extremely knowledgeable in all the dishes, and were quick to offer suggestions that would suit our needs. The one thing i did notice was the amount of wait staff. Although there were a heap, you didn't feel pestered or "watched" over the course of the meal. I can highly recommend the set menu, it has very generous servings, and is great value for money. Also from the dessert menu, the lemongrass chili and lavender rose sorbet was the highlight of the night. Even though we had a little mix up with desserts and the cloak room, the overall experience was not tarnished by these things. Two big thumbs up!!
